title: El caótico arancel de Trump
content: Pasan los días y aún no hay claridad sobre cómo quedará el arancel de los EE. UU. para los productos que exporta Ecuador. Trump impuso provisionalmente un arancel recíproco de 10 % a todas las ...
resumen:
Pasan los días y aún no hay claridad sobre cómo quedará el arancel de los EE. UU. para los productos que exporta Ecuador. Trump impuso provisionalmente un arancel recíproco de 10 % a todas las naciones, salvo a las que castiga más fuertemente, y planteó que todos los países tenían que negociar aranceles con Washington. El plazo de definición es ahora agosto 1, y se desconoce si el 10 % es el impuesto mínimo, o si se va a sumar al anterior. Ecuador debería bregar por que el 10 % no se sume sino que substituya a los aranceles existentes, por ejemplo, rosas de 6,8 % a 10 % y no 16,8 %.

En general, para los productos que nos interesan, el alza arancelaria para Ecuador sería inferior que aquella para nuestros competidores. Sería el caso del camarón, atún y cacao. En banano no habría mayor efecto, pero las rosas serían más vulnerables.

Camarón: el cálculo es complicado porque para proteger a la flota camaronera, EE. UU. impone dos tipos de recargos que pueden variar de empresa a empresa, pero que es posible conseguir su eliminación. Sumando el 10 % del arancel recíproco, el camarón nacional pagaría un arancel más recargo de 24 % en promedio, similar al de Indonesia (23 %). Ecuador estaría en ventaja frente a otros proveedores. Para la India, que tiene el 38 % del mercado, el arancel más recargos sería 30 %. Pero es posible que la India consiga una reducción del arancel. Los otros competidores tendrían una carga arancelaria incluso mayor: Tailandia (37 %) y Vietnam (61 %).

Atún enlatado en agua. Ahora el arancel subiría a 22 %, pero como Trump está gravando alto productos del sudeste de Asia, estos pagarían más: Tailandia, el mayor proveedor, 48 %; Vietnam, Filipinas e Indonesia, 31-32 %. México podría cabildear para entrar con 0 % arancel.

Cacao: todos los proveedores importantes de EE. UU. tendrían el arancel recíproco de 10 %, excepto Costa de Marfil, el mayor exportador mundial y principal proveedor de EE. UU., con el 21 %. Lo que podrían aprovechar Ecuador y Ghana, segundo y tercer abastecedor.

Banano: de 0 % pasamos a 10 %. Pero igual el banano de países centroamericanos y Colombia con que competimos a pesar que todos ellos tienen acuerdos comerciales. Pero se entiende que a México no se le recargará ese 10 % debido a su acuerdo comercial, lo que llevaría a México a importar banano centroamericano para su consumo interno y destinar el suyo para exportar a EE. UU. México hoy suministra aproximadamente el 7 % del banano importado por EE. UU. Si México incrementa su producción, afectaría la exportación de los demás, incluyendo Ecuador.

Rosas: el arancel para Ecuador y Colombia subiría 10 %: a Colombia a 10 % y a Ecuador a 16,8 %. Pero México podría convertirse en competidor gracias a 0 % de arancel.

title: Trump touts ‘biggest deal ever made’ as US and EU sketch trade framework
content: President Donald Trump announced Sunday that the United States and the European Union reached a framework for a trade deal, ending a monthslong saga with America’s largest trading partner.

title: Trump’s latest clumsy deal has unintended consequences
content: The threat of a full-scale trans-Atlantic trade war has been averted with a deal between the US and the EU, but there is some confusion over just what has been agreed to.
resumen: A deal was struck between the US and European Union, averting a trans-Atlantic trade war. Both sides have differing interpretations of what they’ve agreed to. The deal imposes a baseline tariff of 15 per cent on all EU exports to the US. Before Trump regained office, the average tariff on EU exports was 2.5 per cent. Ursula von der Leyen said the new rate would apply to European cars, pharmaceuticals and semiconductors, while Donald Trump said pharmaceuticals were “unrelated to this deal”. The US has separate investigations of pharmaceuticals and semiconductors under way that could lead to sectoral tariffs on imports of those products. Trump said the new baseline tariff was in exchange for the EU “opening up their countries at zero tariff”, whereas the EU says the agreement for “zero for zero” tariffs relates to certain strategic products and their parts, such as chemicals, semiconductor equipment and some agricultural products. The deal has been described as a “road map” for a detailed agreement rather than a conventional trade deal. The agreement would also have to be ratified by the European Parliament and the 27 individual national parliaments of the EU’s members before it could take effect. The deal envisages the EU buying a lot of US energy – $US750 billion ($1.14 trillion) of energy over the next three years, as well as weaponry. Trump also said the EU would invest $US600 billion in the US. The EU now imports about half its LNG from the US. The deals have unintended consequences for American companies, consumers and the US economy. The promise to invest $US600 billion in the US was vague. The investment agreement with the EU appears just a broad statement of intent. The Japanese have agreed to provide equity, loans and loan guarantees for investments in the US. Trump said Japan would invest, “at my discretion”, the $US550 billion. The presentation card on Trump’s desk originally said Japan would invest $US400 billion, but the “$400B” was crossed out and altered to $US500 billion. When Trump announced the detail, it had suddenly become $US550 billion. The 15 per cent tariff on European vehicle and vehicle part exports is a big win for the Europeans. Thanks to Trump, who has imposed 25 per cent duties on imports of steel, aluminium, vehicle parts and those components of US vehicles not made within the US, the European and Japanese companies will have a material competitive advantage over America’s own carmakers.

title: Trump's Trade Deals Won't End the Harm Caused by His Tariffs
content: All told Trump's IEEPA tariffs are expected to impose some $1.9 trillion in tax increases on Americans over the next decade, costing the average household some $1000 per year, while also raising ...
resumen: Trump has reached trade deals with the European Union, the UK, Japan, Vietnam, and the Philippines. In each case, tariff rates under the deals are vastly higher than they were before Trump started his trade war. The new tariff on most EU goods will be 15%, compared to an average rate of 1.47% before Trump's second term (the EU imposed an average %1.35 rate on US imports). It's a similar story with Japan (15% vs. 2%), Britain (10% vs. 3.3%), and the others. Under the Administration's interpretation of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA), Trump would retain unfettered discretion to raise tariffs further any time he wants for any reason. Trump's IEEPA tariffs are expected to impose some $1.9 trillion in tax increases on Americans over the next decade, costing the average household some $1000 per year. The relatively modest reductions in tariffs against US exports these deals include (e.g. Britain reduced its tariffs from an average of 3.8% to 1.8%) don't even begin to offset the enormous harm. The Liberty Justice Center and I secured a ruling against the "Liberation Day" tariffs in the US Court of International Trade, and our case (together with one filed by 12 state governments) is now on appeal in the Federal Circuit.

title: Here's a puzzling question: Why are stocks at record highs despite looming tariffs?
content: President Trump's tariffs could hit the economy badly and lead to higher inflation. But Wall Street investors are reacting by sending stocks to record highs.
resumen:
President Trump's tariffs could hit the economy badly and lead to higher inflation. Wall Street investors are reacting by sending stocks to record highs.

The S&P 500 and the tech-heavy Nasdaq have hit a recent string of record highs.

The economy has held up much better than many expected. Inflation ticked up to 2.7% in June from a year earlier. The unemployment rate is still at a historically low rate of 4.1%.

Brad Peterson, national portfolio adviser at Northern Trust, says the economy has proven to be more resilient than many feared in the face of tariff threats.

The U.S. economy is expected to grow at a slower pace in the second half of the year than in 2024, with the chance of a recession seen at 33% in the next 12 months, according to the latest quarterly survey from The Wall Street Journal.

Corporate earnings are proving sturdier than what many in the markets had initially feared.

Companies such as Alphabet (the parent company of Google), Netflix, AT&T and Hasbro beat Wall Street expectations.

Delta Air Lines said travelers are feeling more confident despite the tariff uncertainty.

Amanda Agati, the chief investment officer for PNC Asset Management Group in Philadelphia, says "We may feel bad. We may feel concerned, but the hard data would suggest our behavior is something else entirely".

General Motors announced a $1.1 billion hit to its profit because of higher tariffs.

Kevin Gordon, a senior investment strategist at the Schwab Center for Financial Research in New York, says small businesses struggle a lot more from higher tariffs because they just don't have the kind of flexibility or the cash balances that large companies do to be able to combat it.

When Trump first announced his round of tariffs in early April, stocks took a nosedive. Stocks rebounded sharply after Trump then announced a 90-day pause — which has now been extended a second time to Friday. The president did retain the baseline 10% tariff on just about everything the U.S. imports, while imposing other tariffs on some items such as steel and aluminum.

Trump announced a trade deal with Japan, saying the U.S. will impose a 15% tariff on imports from Asia's second-largest economy.

The new tariff helped send the S&P 500 to yet another record high.

Trinh Nguyen, senior economist for emerging Asia at Natixis, posted on X, "We live in a new normal where 10% is the new zero and so 15% and 20% doesn't seem so bad if everyone else got it".

The average tariff rate is still at the highest it has been since the 1930s.

Sandy Villere, a partner and portfolio manager at Villere & Co. in New Orleans, says markets could fall by 10% to 12% from current levels in the second half of the year.

title: US Fed poised to defy Trump on interest rate cuts
content: The US central bank is widely expected to hold off slashing interest rates again at its upcoming meeting, as officials gather under the cloud of an intensifying pressure campaign by US President ...
resumen: The US central bank is widely expected to hold off slashing interest rates again at its upcoming meeting. Policymakers at the independent US Federal Reserve have kept the benchmark lending rate steady since the start of the year. The bank meets tomorrow and Wednesday. The Fed seeks a balance between reining in inflation and the health of the jobs market. The Fed’s benchmark lending rate stands at a range between 4.25 percent and 4.50 percent. US President Donald Trump has repeatedly criticized Fed Chair Jerome Powell for not slashing rates further, calling him a “numbskull” and “moron.” Trump signaled he could use the Fed’s US$2.5 billion renovation project as an avenue to oust Powell. Trump visited the Fed construction site on Thursday last week, making a tense appearance with Powell. Economists expect the Fed to look past the political pressure at its policy meeting. Oxford Economics chief US economist Ryan Sweet said, “We’re just now beginning to see the evidence of tariffs’ impact on inflation.” Powell’s term as Fed chair ends in May next year. Fed Governor Christopher Waller and Vice Chair for Supervision Michelle Bowman have both signaled openness to rate cuts early this month. Nationwide chief economist Kathy Bostjancic said too many dissents could be “eyebrow-raising.”

title: Tariffs aren't good news but it could have been much worse
content: While the crucial EU-US trade deal announced this weekend does bring certainty for businesses, there are significant drawbacks.
resumen: The crucial US EU trade deal announced this weekend brings certainty for businesses, but there are significant drawbacks. Tariffs are negative for trade. The US is a significant export market for Ireland, and many sectors now face duties of 15% which did not exist last year. The biggest issue is pharmaceuticals, which are the largest Irish export to the US, valued at €44bn in 2024. US President Donald Trump had threatened enormous duties on drugs imported by America and ordered a national security investigation of the pharmaceutical sector. Tánaiste Simon Harris said his understanding was that after the investigation concludes the maximum tariff which could be imposed would be 15%. Pharmaceuticals made in Ireland may well face 15% tariffs in future, up from zero at present. A decision on tariffs on spirits is critically important to Ireland's whiskey industry. Another key sector for Ireland is the manufacture of computer chips. It has been subject to a separate investigation by the Trump administration and faced the possibility of punitive tariffs, but it too could face a 15% tariff after the investigation ends. European Commission President Ursula Von Der Leyen said there was no decision yet regarding spirits exported to the US. This is critically important to Ireland's whiskey industry which has already seen several recent closures. There had been speculation that sector could have been part of a zero-for-zero tariff arrangement, but that is not yet agreed. Another important area for Ireland is aircraft leasing. Ms Von Der Leyen said last night that aviation would be part of a tariff-free arrangement. For other EU countries the massive duty of 27.5% which was imposed on European cars now falls to 15%. Some existing tariffs will be folded into that baseline 15%, meaning it would be an all-in tariff. It is expected to include the existing "most favoured nation" duties of 4.8% which exist currently under World Trade Organization rules. The fact there is a deal at all avoids the threat of a prolonged tit-for-tat trade war. It means businesses can plan, investments can be made, and job-creating projects can proceed. Exporters are already seeking Government support as they navigate the new reality of the Trump administration’s tariffs. The EU-US agreement is not a trade deal in the usual sense. What was announced yesterday was the framework of a deal with much detail yet to be finalised. Yesterday wasn’t the end of the negotiations, but it was a milestone.

title: Nvidia AI Chips $1 Billion Smuggled to China Despite Trump Export Controls
content: B in Nvidia AI chips reportedly smuggled to China despite Trump export controls, raising questions about efficacy of US sanctions on tech ...
resumen:
Despite the Trump administration’s stricter export controls on advanced semiconductor technology, at least $1 billion worth of advanced AI chips of Nvidia found their way to China through sophisticated networks of smugglers within three months of the controls.

The prohibited chips–such as Nvidia’s top-of-the-line B200, H100, and H200 models–are the exact same chips used by the world’s most sophisticated artificial intelligence systems on the planet today.

The smuggling networks coordinated whole server racks of the illicit processors and had them sent directly to Chinese data centers.

By May 2025, Chinese vendors started openly marketing these prohibited chips to AI-oriented data center operators.

Industry experts estimated the number of such prohibited Nvidia chips to be between 10,000 and hundreds of thousands that found their way into China in 2024 alone.

Singaporean authorities arrested people involved in suspected theft of $390 million servers that were ultimately bound for China.

Nvidia claimed that it is technically difficult and economically unviable to build data centers using smuggled chips, as Nvidia only offers service and support for products sold through official channels.

The Trump administration and U.S. Commerce Department put numbers to the extent of the issue and took steps to investigate new legislation aimed at improving AI chip tracing.

In July 2025, Trump issued a license to allow Nvidia to resume selling some chips namely the H20 model to China.

Nvidia’s China business generated $17 billion in revenue last fiscal year nearly 13% of the company’s overall revenue.

title: Trump sets EU tariff at 15%, lower than his original threat, after meeting in Scotland
content: Trump had most recently threatened tariffs of 30% on imports from the European Union. But on Sunday, he met with the president of the European Commission, and they agreed to a lower level.
resumen:
President Trump announced a trade deal with the European Union on Sunday after meeting with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen at his golf course in Scotland.

Under the agreement, most EU exports to the United States will face a 15% tariff, down from the 30% tariff that Trump had most recently threatened. The EU has agreed to accept U.S. imports without tariffs.

Steel, aluminum, and pharmaceuticals will not be included in the deal.

The EU agreed to buy $750 billion worth of U.S. energy as part of the agreement, and to invest $600 billion into the United States, according to Trump.

Trump met with Ursula von der Leyen on July 27, 2025, at his golf resort in Turnberry, Scotland.

title: Increase this week in Trump's Mexico tariffs could strain Texas economy
content: The possibility of a 30% tariff this week “is a game changer,” said Dante Galeazzi, CEO and president of the Texas International Produce ...
resumen:
Importers and exporters based in Texas have so far avoided the harshest effects of the trade war sparked by President Donald Trump’s tariffs on imports from a host of countries, but they could be in for a rude awakening this week.

Mexico, which is Texas’ largest trading partner, has been largely exempt from tariffs due to a March agreement that allowed an estimated 85% to 90% of all Mexican goods to avoid the 25% tariff the Trump administration placed on its imports.

Trump this month told Mexico, two dozen other countries and the European Union that their exports will face an increase of the tax on their goods unless they quickly negotiate new trade deals with the U.S. Trump’s letter to Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum promises to raise the rate against the country to 30% on Aug. 1 and makes no mention of extending the spring agreement exempting most Mexican imports.

Dante Galeazzi, CEO and president of the Texas International Produce Association, said, “When we talk about the possibility of a 30% tariff, that is a game changer.” His organization represents 400 Texas companies throughout the produce supply chain that grow or import $13 billion worth of produce annually.

Two-way trade between the U.S. and Mexico totaled $840 billion last year. Texas traded a total of $281 billion with Mexico in 2024, according to the Office of the United States Trade Representative.

The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, negotiated by the three countries during Trump’s first term, aimed to eliminate trade barriers and level the playing field between the three countries’ labor and manufacturing sectors.

In March, two months into Trump’s second term, U.S. trade policy with its two biggest trading partners has see-sawed dramatically, briefly putting in place a 25% tariff on Mexican and Canadian goods before a deal was announced two days later to exempt all USMCA-compliant goods from the tariff.

Craig Slate, CEO and president of Arizona-based Mexican produce importer SunFed, which operates in Texas, said, “Back in March was super difficult, super stressful, lots of preparation getting ready for it.”

Trump cited the flow of fentanyl across both the northern and southern borders as the basis for the tariffs in March. Mexico and Canada promised retaliatory tariffs. Then, the deal was announced to exempt most goods traded between the three countries from the tariffs for 30 days and later extended a further 90 days in April.

Economists fear the economy could again face difficulties like those seen in March because the tariff rate for most trade in North America could effectively jump from 0% to 30% if the USMCA exemptions are not kept in place.

Ed Hirs, an economist and energy fellow at the University of Houston, said, “It’s going to be devastating to U.S.-Mexico trade.”

For SunFed, the effect of the jump in tariffs could be painful, Slate said. SunFed is the company that pays the tariff to the U.S. government on its imported goods, which includes watermelons, squash, bell peppers, cucumbers and cantaloupe.

Slate said he believes it’s more likely they will see shortages of certain products in the future because farmers or importers will decide it’s not worth the financial risk of importing products to the U.S.

A 50% tariff on aluminum and steel in place since early June is driving a “notable pickup” in cost in Texas’ manufacturing sector, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas’ July report on the health of the region’s economy.

Trump announced a 50% tariff on copper that will go into effect on Aug. 1, which is expected to further increase manufacturing costs, Hirs said.

U.S. Rep. Tony Gonzales, R-San Antonio, said, “I’m very focused on the Aug. 1 date. What that means is President Trump has given us a couple weeks to try to come up with a solution, and I’ve seen Mexico … change, from months ago basically being allowed to do whatever they want to … all of the sudden, they’re coming to the table.”

Glenn Hamer, president and CEO of the Texas Association of Business, cited Texas’ status as the eighth-largest economy in the world.

A spokesperson for Gov. Greg Abbott said the trade war is an opportunity to “reset” global supply chains.

Hamer, trade war opponents and Texas businesses also say a 30% tariff on goods currently covered by the USMCA could be difficult for the Texas economy.

Galeazzi said, “We learned firsthand and painfully during COVID that once you disrupt the supply chain, it never returns to exactly how it was.”

Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney on Tuesday downplayed the possibility of that happening.

Sheinbaum said on July 12, “We believe … we are going to reach an agreement with the United States government and, of course, achieve better terms.”

Hamer said, “We’d like to see predictability and stability in our tariff policy as soon as possible.”

title: Trump ve '50 % de probabilidad' de acuerdo arancelario con UE, pero para ello pide equidad
content: Von der Leyen, por su parte, remarcó que EE.UU. y la UE "son las mayores economías del mundo", con un volumen comercial de 1,7 billones de dólares, y reconoció que se trata de "reequilibrar" la relaci ...
resumen:
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, reafirmó que ve "un 50 % de probabilidad" de alcanzar un acuerdo arancelario con la Unión Europea, pero señaló que "la falta de equidad" supuestamente por parte de Bruselas es uno de los obstáculos para conseguirlo.

Trump hizo estas declaraciones al inicio de su reunión en su complejo de golf de Turnberry, en el oeste de Escocia, con la presidenta de la Comisión Europea, Ursula von de Leyen, quien por su parte confió en cerrar el que sería "el mayo acuerdo del mundo".

"Si no llegamos a un pacto, habrá aranceles", afirmó el líder republicano, en alusión a su amenaza de aplicar unilateralmente tarifas fijas del 30 % a las importaciones comunitarias a partir del 1 de agosto.

Von der Leyen, por su parte, remarcó que EE.UU. y la UE "son las mayores economías del mundo", con un volumen comercial de 1,7 billones de dólares, y reconoció que se trata de "reequilibrar" la relación bilateral dado que Estados Unidos tiene un déficit comercial con los Veintisiete.

Trump también rechazó que su Administración esté dispuesta a ofrecer menos de un 15 % de aranceles al bloque comunitario, que es el porcentaje que, según fuentes de la negociación, se estaría pactando como solución de compromiso para evitar una guerra comercial por ambas partes a partir de agosto.

Aunque la intención es colaborativa, Von der Leyen llega a la cita respaldada por un paquete de contramedidas de represalia por valor de 93,000 millones de euros, que se aplicarían de forma escalonada si no hay entendimiento.

title: EU-US Trade Pact Halves Tariffs, Avoids Trade War
content: The United States and European Union reached a significant trade agreement that slashed tariffs on EU goods to 15%, avoiding a larger trade conflict. The deal promises EU investments in the U.S. and ...
resumen: The United States and European Union reached a trade agreement that slashed tariffs on EU goods to 15%, avoiding a larger trade conflict. The deal promises EU investments in the U.S. and increased purchases of U.S. energy and arms. The agreement stabilizes trade relations and benefits both economies. The United States and the European Union have agreed on a trade framework, cutting import tariffs on EU goods to 15%, averting a major trade war. This agreement, announced by U.S. President Donald Trump and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, is said to strengthen the trans-Atlantic economic ties. President Trump described the deal as historic, highlighting plans for the EU to significantly invest and purchase U.S. energy and military equipment. Despite some concerns over the tariffs' rate, the agreement is viewed favorably by many, including German Chancellor Friedrich Merz, as it avoids a potential trade conflict. However, there are criticisms regarding the deal's high-level nature and tariff imbalances. While it secures tariffs on key sectors like semiconductors and pharmaceuticals, questions remain, particularly concerning the impact on U.S.–EU spirits trade and existing steel and aluminum tariffs. Nevertheless, officials from both sides believe the agreement fosters stability and predictability in global trade.

title: The Risk Of Rushing: Details Murky On Trump, Van Der Leyen Trade Deal
content: United States, European Union stave off 30% U.S. tariffs on imports, due to start on Friday, at least for now. But what about pharmaceuticals?
resumen:
President Trump and European Union President Ursula von der Leyen shook hands on a deal Sunday to stave off 30% tariffs on U.S. imports from the E.U., though it remains unclear what the deal is.

It appears that most if not all U.S. imports from the European Union will face a 15% tariff.

It also appears that most U.S. exports to the 27 nations of the European Union will not have a tariff.

The 15% tariff on U.S. imports is up slightly from the 10% “baseline” tariff already in place with all countries of the world since Trump began the global trade war to reduce the U.S. deficit.

The “deal” would seem to lower the 25% tariff in place on passenger vehicle imports into the United States.

The zero tariff rate would replace a rate of 2.8% on the U.S. export side.

A spokesperson for the European Union would not respond to a “request for comment about Trump’s claim."

Does the 15% tariff on E.U. imports include critical medicines and the compounds used to make those medicines, imports into the United States that Ireland and other European nations dominate?

President Trump says no, according to one news source.

“We have 15% for pharmaceuticals,” Von der Leyen said, according to another.

The United States’ top 15 trade partners, which account for 44.40% of all U.S. trade, including 44.22% of all U.S. exports and 44.51% of all imports, includes the following seven European Union nations:

No. 4 Germany,
No. 6 Switzerland,
No. 7. Ireland,
No. 11 United Kingdom,
No. 13 the Netherlands,
No. 14 France,
No. 15 Italy.

The trade with just these European Union nations is relatively balanced, with those seven accounting for 21.38% of all U.S. trade, including 20.27% of all exports and 22.05% of all U.S. imports. The overall deficit with these five nations is $149.61 billion.

The European Union is accounting for 20.22% of all U.S. imports and 18.57% of all U.S. exports through May, the latest data available from the U.S. Census Bureau.

Six of the 10 U.S. imports from the European Union where the E.U. was a dominant source were in the area of pharmaceuticals and with chemical compounds used to make medicines in this country. The same six in 10 statistic is true of U.S. exports to the 27-nation European Union.

99.22% of $42.95 billion in U.S. imports in the insulin, hormone and steroid category (HS code 2937) through May were from the European Union, with 98.48% coming from Ireland. It is the top U.S. import from the European Union this year.

The same category is a top U.S. export to the European Union, accounting for 53.85% of the $4.94 billion in U.S. exports to the world, ranking fourth overall to the European Union.

The European Union is responsible for 79.77% of the $2.97 billion in wine imports into the United States through May and 80.78% of $2.15 billion in perfumes.

Passenger vehicles (HS code 8703), with a 19.80% of the $81.07 billion total.

Jet engines and parts (HS code 8411), with 37.86% of the $13.06 billion in U.S. imports from the European Union.

Medical instruments (HS code 9018), which includes everything from needles and catheters to MRI machines and parts, with 24.87% of the $18.57 billion total from the European Union.

Artificial knee, hip joints and other body parts (HS code 9021), with 51.64% of the total $8.06 billion imported from the world through May coming from the European Union.

The European Union has an appetite for the broad nut category (HS code 0802) that is dominated by shelled almonds and pistachios in the shell, with 37.49% of the $4.09 billion total in U.S. exports through May headed to the European Union. In addition, the E.U. has a thirst for the alcoholic spirits category (HS code 2208) that is dominated by bourbon and whiskey, with 46.66% of the total $1.08 billion sent to the world.

The European Union would be buying $750 billion in U.S. energy products.

In 2024, U.S. exports to the world of oil, gasoline and other refined petroleum products, and natural gas such as LNG – the dominant categories – was less than $300 billion.

Oil (HS code 2709), with 36.62% of the total $43.21 billion in U.S. exports to the world headed to the European Union through May. This is the top U.S. export to the European Union.

Petroleum gas, which includes liquid natural gas, or LNG (HS code 2711), with 37.37% of the total $35.56 billion in U.S. shipments to the world. This is the third-ranked U.S. export to the European Union through May.

Passenger vehicles (HS code 8703), with 21.09% of the $22.42 billion in exports to the world sent to the nations of the European Union. This is the No. 8-ranked U.S. export there this year.

title: Trump Administration Live Updates: Preliminary E.U. Trade Deal Reached After Months of Tense Talks
content: The deal, which would set a 15 percent tariff on most E.U. goods, averted what could have become a painful trade war with the United States’ biggest source of imports. “We are agreeing that the tariff ...
resumen: The European Union and the United States agreed on Sunday to a broad-brush trade deal that sets a 15 percent tariff on most E.U. goods, including cars and pharmaceuticals. The deal sets a 15 percent tariff on European goods imported to the U.S. The United States and the European Union also agreed to drop tariffs to zero on a range of goods, including aircraft, plane parts, certain chemicals, certain generic drugs, semiconductor equipment and some agricultural products. President Trump said that the European Union had agreed to purchase $750 billion of American energy, which Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the E.U.’s executive branch, said would be spread out over three years. The 27-nation bloc also agreed to increase its investment in the United States by more than $600 billion above current levels, Mr. Trump said, adding that the European Union would buy military equipment. A senior U.S. official said that those investments would include pharmaceuticals and the automotive industry, among others. The two sides also agreed to drop tariffs to zero on a range of goods, including aircraft, plane parts, certain chemicals, certain generic drugs, semiconductor equipment and some agricultural products, Ms. von der Leyen said. The 15 percent tariff rate given to Europe mirrors the main tariff rate of the U.S.-Japanese trade agreement that was announced last Tuesday. A senior U.S. official said the 50 percent tariff the Trump administration had imposed on steel and aluminum globally was not part of the deal. The U.S. official added that European pharmaceutical and semiconductor exports will be subject to a 15 percent tariff. The administration is currently preparing an investigation that will apply tariffs to those sectors globally, which the official said could come in two or three weeks. Pharmaceuticals are Europe’s most important export to the United States. Ms. von der Leyen said that no decisions had been made yet on whether wine and spirits would be exempt. The European Union last year accounted for nearly $610 billion of the $3.3 trillion in goods imported by the United States. The European Union also agreed to purchase $750 billion of American energy. The bloc also agreed to increase its investment in the United States by more than $600 billion.

title: U.S. Reaches Preliminary Trade Deal With Europe
content: The United States and the European Union agreed to a 15 percent base tariff after weeks of negotiations, which were among the Trump administration’s most difficult discussions.
resumen:
The European Union and the United States agreed on Sunday to a broad-brush trade deal that sets a 15 percent tariff on most E.U. goods, including cars and pharmaceuticals.

President Trump said that the European Union had agreed to purchase $750 billion of American energy, which Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the E.U.’s executive branch, told reporters would be spread out over three years.

The 27-nation bloc also agreed to increase its investment in the United States by more than $600 billion above current levels, Mr. Trump said, adding that the European Union would buy military equipment. A senior U.S. official said that those investments would include pharmaceuticals and the automotive industry, among others.

The two sides also agreed to drop tariffs to zero on a range of goods, including aircraft, plane parts, certain chemicals, certain generic drugs, semiconductor equipment and some agricultural products, Ms. von der Leyen said.

A senior U.S. official said the 50 percent tariff the Trump administration had imposed on steel and aluminum globally was not part of the deal.

The U.S. official added that European pharmaceutical and semiconductor exports will be subject to a 15 percent tariff.

Ms. von der Leyen said that no decisions had been made yet on whether wine and spirits would be exempt.

The European Union last year accounted for nearly $610 billion of the $3.3 trillion in goods imported by the United States.

The 15 percent tariff rate given to Europe mirrors the main tariff rate of the U.S.-Japanese trade agreement that was announced last Tuesday, and is lower than the 19 and 20 percent rates imposed on several Southeast Asian countries. But it is higher than the 10 percent tax that Europeans had been angling for, and that Mr. Trump applied to British goods.

According to the World Trade Organization, before Mr. Trump came into office, the trade-weighted tariff the United States charged on foreign goods was 2.2 percent, while the European Union’s was 2.7 percent.

Mr. Trump imposed a 25 percent tariff on foreign cars and car parts in April. European automakers, which sent cars worth 38.5 billion euros ($45 billion) to the United States last year.

Mr. Trump also lowered the tariff rate on Japanese auto exports to 15 percent as part of the deal announced last week.

title: Japan’s post-upper-house election crisis
content: The LDP’s poor upper house result compounds uncertainty at a time when Japan’s quiet leadership is critical for regional stability and the defence of the multilateral project.
resumen:
Japan’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party and its coalition partner Komeito suffered a decisive defeat in the July 2025 upper house election, failing to win a majority for the second consecutive election. Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba is set to resign by the end of August following overwhelming pressure from within his own party, leaving the LDP fractured. The incoming prime minister will inherit a weakened party struggling with corruption scandals while navigating difficult negotiations with opposition parties to form a government. Japan must also manage unpredictable trade relations with the Trump administration, including a costly tariff deal that offers no guarantee of long-term stability.

Japan’s ruling Liberal Democratic Party and its junior coalition partner Komeito failed to win a majority for the second election in a row. After the upper house election on 20 July, the government is now in the minority in both houses of parliament. Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba is reportedly set to resign by the end of August. If he does, whoever replaces Ishiba will face formidable challenges to unite the LDP; navigate tricky negotiations with opposition parties; regain Japanese public trust; boost economic growth; and manage alliance relations with the ever-erratic Donald Trump.

The election loss has exposed the LDP’s political weakness. Of the 125 seats up for election, the LDP won just 39, a loss of 13 seats. With Komeito’s eight seats, the ruling coalition won just 47 seats. Counting those upper house seats not contested during this election cycle, the LDP–Komeito coalition has 122 to 126 scattered among opposition parties.

Ishiba’s position appears to be untenable. While he initially expressed his intention to stay on as the country’s leader in the immediate aftermath of the election, dissent within his own party has forced his hand. On 23 July, the Mainichi Shimbun reported that he would resign by the end of August after he concluded an agreement in the trade war with the United States. Another reason for his delayed exit may be to buy time to coordinate voting on who would replace him as prime minister.

LDP opposition to Ishiba in the wake of the election moved beyond the usual suspects of his intra-party rivals. Criticism from the arch-conservative Sanae Takaichi, whom Ishiba defeated in the LDP leadership election in September 2024, and members of the former Shinzo Abe faction who are backing her, was to be expected. Calls from junior LDP backbenchers for Ishiba to resign, a number of LDP prefectural branches, as well as a tap on the shoulder in a rare meeting with three former LDP prime ministers — Taro Aso, Yoshihide Suga and Fumio Kishida — on 23 July made pressures for his resignation all but insurmountable.

Once Ishiba resigns as prime minister and leader of the LDP, two separate leadership selection processes will be triggered. First, the LDP will decide on a new leader. Based on the September 2024 party leadership contest won by Ishiba, the contest will boil down once again to two candidates: one backed by the conservative nationalists in the Aso faction and the former Abe faction; and a reformist candidate backed by party elder statesmen like former prime ministers Fumio Kishida and Yoshihide Suga seeking to reinvent the LDP and regain popular support in the wake of the Unification Church and slush fund scandals that kickstarted the LDP’s recent decline. Second, the parliament will vote to select a new prime minister. If no candidate secures a majority in the first round of voting in the lower house, a runoff between the top two candidates would determine the outcome. This scenario may force the LDP to make policy concessions to opposition parties willing to support their candidate, such as those that Ishiba negotiated with the Democratic Party for the People (DPFP). The divided opposition parties — spanning the political spectrum from the Japan Communist Party, the centre-left Constitutional Democratic Party (CDP), the centrist-technocratic DPFP, the neo-liberal Japan Innovation Party and the far-right conspiracist Sanseito — have historically struggled to coordinate effectively, meaning that a new LDP prime minister is the most likely outcome despite the party’s bruising electoral defeat.

The new prime minister must then restore unity within a fractured LDP and regain public trust. The party remains split over how to address the twin crises that triggered its decline: the Unification Church scandal that exposed decades of mutually beneficial arrangements between LDP politicians and the controversial religious organisation, and the political slush fund scandal that revealed systemic campaign finance violations mostly by the former Abe faction. The party’s conservative nationalists, particularly those aligned with the former Abe faction, remain resistant to detailed public accounting that might implicate longtime power brokers, while reformist elements see an opportunity to sideline the national conservatives as the true centre of power in the party.

Adding to these challenges is the emergence of the right-wing nationalist Sanseito, as a significant political force that threatens to further erode the LDP’s support base. The party, which began as a YouTube channel during the COVID-19 pandemic, achieved stunning gains in the July 2025 upper house election, winning 14 seats — a dramatic surge from its previous single seat. Campaigning under the slogan ‘Japanese First’, Sanseito successfully attracted disaffected conservative nationalist voters who had traditionally supported the LDP, capitalising on frustrations over rising living costs, immigration concerns, and what party leader Sohei Kamiya characterised as a ‘silent invasion’ of foreigners.

Sanseito’s social media-driven success poses a dilemma for the LDP: whether to adopt some of its populist rhetoric and conspiracy-tinged messaging to win back voters, or risk further haemorrhaging support to a party that has proven adept at channelling anti-establishment sentiment. Any temptation to embrace Sanseito’s xenophobic appeals or conspiracist style could further damage the LDP’s credibility with moderate voters and international partners. But ignoring the underlying grievances that Sanseito has tapped into may also prove costly.

The Trump playbook creates immediate challenges for an incoming prime minister, who must find ways to deal with Japan’s cost-of-living crisis, including negotiating a tariff deal with the White House. Trump announced a new deal that would reduce tariffs from the threatened 25 per cent to 15 per cent, including for Japan’s flagship auto industry. In exchange, Japan would make concessions on opening up to US autos and agricultural products, as well as make investments in the United States worth US$550 billion. If implemented, this deal amounts to an expensive insurance against Trump’s more aggressive trade threats, trading immediate costs for medium-term stability.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has flagged the prospect of quarterly ‘evaluations’ of Japan’s compliance with the deal, reserving the right to have tariffs ‘boomerang’ to a 25 per cent rate if the ‘President is unhappy’.

content: US-China officials to meet in Stockholm amid trade tensions. Talks expected to maintain current tariff levels while working towards future summit.

title: High-Stakes Trade Talks: US and China Negotiations Move to Stockholm
content: Upcoming trade talks in Stockholm will see top US and Chinese officials attempt to stabilize economic tensions, with a focus on tariffs and structural reforms. The discussions aim to pave the way for ...
resumen: Upcoming trade talks in Stockholm will see top US and Chinese officials attempt to stabilize economic tensions, with a focus on tariffs and structural reforms. The discussions aim to pave the way for a potential fall meeting between President Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping, targeting balanced economic relations. In Stockholm, pivotal trade talks between US and Chinese officials might see tensions ease as the two economic superpowers negotiate current tariff levels and discuss potential structural reforms. This meeting holds the potential to lay groundwork for a forthcoming summit between President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The stakes are high, as both nations aim to address lingering economic issues, including significant trade deficits and China's regulatory measures on precursor chemicals for fentanyl. The US seeks to enhance its export opportunities to China, while Beijing demands easing of US tariffs, including those related to fentanyl, to resolve trade disputes. Saturday's negotiations could shape the future economic landscape, with leaders from both sides striving for comprehensive agreements that might involve shifts in US military presence in East Asia and diplomatic adjustments regarding Taiwan. As global trade tensions mount, the world watches to see if a path to resolution can indeed be achieved.

title: Hang Seng Index News: Trade Talk Hopes Lift Sentiment as 26,000 Resistance Looms
content: Hang Seng Index climbs on US-EU trade deal hopes and tech gains; focus shifts to US-China talks and Beijing’s next policy move.
resumen: The Hang Seng Index rose on trade deal hopes, but sentiment hinges on US-China talks and Beijing’s next policy moves. A US-China trade agreement with lower tariffs may push the Index above 26,000 toward the 27,000 resistance level. EV stock losses offset tech gains, dragging the Hang Seng TECH Index into negative territory despite Alibaba's rally. The Hang Seng Index advanced in early trading on Monday, July 28, reversing Friday’s losses. Investors reacted to the US and the EU reaching a trade deal, lifting hopes for a US-China trade agreement. The US and China’s third round of high-level trade talks kicks off later today. This week, trade developments, China’s private sector PMI data on July 31, and Beijing policy updates will affect market sentiment. These key drivers will determine whether the Index drops below 25,000 or rises above 26,000. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.57% to 25,534 in morning trading on July 28, eyeing the 26,000 level. Mainland China markets also trended higher. The CSI 300 and the Shanghai Composite Index posted early gains of 0.11% and 0.03%, respectively. Tech heavyweights Alibaba (9988) and JD.com (9618) led the way in Monday’s morning session, rising 2.12% and 0.84%, respectively. Electric vehicle (EV) shares offset the gains, leaving the Hang Seng TECH Index down 0.05%. EV stocks BYD (1211) and Li Auto (2015) fell 0.54% and 1.28%, respectively, dragging the Tech Index into the red. After the morning gains, the Hang Seng Index trades comfortably above its July congestion zone and the 50-day Exponential Moving Average (EMA). A US-China trade deal, including lower US tariffs on Chinese goods and easing export restrictions, could send the Hang Seng Index toward 26,000. A breakout above 26,000 could pave the way to 27,000. The risk of stalled trade talks exposes the Hang Seng to a reversal, with 25,500 the next key support level. Rising US-China trade tensions would likely weigh on risk appetite, potentially exposing the 25,000 level. Resistance: 26,000, then 27,000. Support: 25,500, followed by 25,000, and the 50-day EMA (24,118). The short-term bias remains bullish but hinges on a US-China trade deal and fresh policy from Beijing. A one-sided trade deal, including zero tariffs on US goods and US levies on Chinese shipments, could raise concerns about China sticking to any agreement. A trade deal maintaining existing US tariffs could weigh on Chinese exports and challenge Beijing’s 5% GDP growth target for 2025. Exports rose 5.8% year-on-year (YoY) in June, up from 4.8% in May. China’s economy expanded 5.2% YoY in Q2.

title: ‘America needs fireworks’: No alternative for some Chinese goods amid trade uncertainty
content: The Trump administration has slapped additional 30 per cent tariffs on China since the trade war began. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen: Fourth of July celebrations in the US may have just passed, but Chinese businessman Marx Wu is already prepared for the dampening effect of tariffs on sales of his fireworks to American customers for the festivities in 2026. This is due to the additional 30 per cent tariffs that US President Donald Trump has been imposing on China. Mr Wu's company, Magnus Fireworks, is based in Hunan province’s Liu­yang city, which is dubbed China’s “fireworks’ home town”. The US government now collects a 35.7 per cent tax from American importers of fireworks from China. 90 per cent of professional display fireworks used in the US are imported from China. US companies import close to US$400 million (S$512 million) worth of consumer fireworks from China each year. China’s exports to the US declined by 10.7 per cent in the first half of 2025 compared with the same period in 2024, a drop of US$25.7 billion. Mr Stephen Olson, a visiting senior fellow at the ISEAS – Yusof Ishak Institute in Singapore who specialises in international trade, said that despite the conflict and tension, trade between the US and China has remained remarkably resilient. Mr Steve Houser, president of Missouri-based Red Rhino Fireworks, said he has already placed his orders for 2026 but added that he – like other major importers – was doing so much more cautiously. The National Fireworks Association in the US was recently in Washington, DC, to make the case that fireworks should be exempt from the across-the-board tariffs of 30 per cent, as there are no viable alternative suppliers from other countries. Mr Wu Xiaoming, chief executive of Aokai Sporting Goods in Yiwu, counts the South American and African markets as his major customers – at about 50 per cent and 20 per cent respectively – with the US market accounting for only about 5 per cent.

title: Bloomberg Daybreak Asia: US, EU Strike Trade Agreement
content: Live market coverage co-anchored from Hong Kong and New York. Overnight on Wall Street is daytime in Asia. Markets never sleep, and neither does Bloomberg.
resumen: Stock-index futures climbed after the European Union struck a deal with President Donald Trump that will see the bloc face 15% tariffs on most exports, averting a potentially damaging trade war. S&P 500 contracts rose 0.4% and those for European stocks jumped 1%. The euro was slightly stronger against the dollar after the US-EU deal. Asian shares fluctuated at the open as Japanese equities declined 0.4%. Treasuries dipped slightly with yields on the 10-year gaining one basis point to 4.4%. Gold edged lower and oil was marginally higher. Investors are bracing for a busy week of data - including meetings of the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan - and earnings from megacap companies that could set the tone for the rest of the year in markets and the economy. Stocks have risen from their slump in April as investors speculate the US will strike trade deals with countries and that will help avoid significant damage to company earnings and the global economy. Australia and the UK signed a landmark 50-year defense treaty on Saturday to underpin the construction of nuclear-powered submarines, senior ministers from both nations said. Both sides stressed that the treaty doesn't impact the AUKUS security partnership between Australia, the UK and the US - currently under review by the Trump administration.

title: EU-US trade war looms as an uneven agreement takes shape
content: With one week left before Donald Trump's deadline for a deal, with threats to impose 30% tariffs on European imports, Brussels scrambles to avert a trade war. A partial agreement is emerging, but it ...
resumen:
Con una semana antes de la fecha límite del 1 de agosto impuesta por Donald Trump, quien amenaza con imponer aranceles del 30% a las importaciones europeas si no se llega a un acuerdo entre Washington y Bruselas, Bruselas se esfuerza por evitar una guerra comercial. Se está gestando un acuerdo parcial, pero sigue siendo incierto dada la imprevisibilidad de Trump.

Donald Trump ha aumentado los aranceles al 25% para los automóviles, al 50% para el acero y el aluminio y al 10% para una amplia gama de productos. También ha advertido que podría apuntar a productos farmacéuticos o semiconductores.

La Comisión de la UE y la administración estadounidense han estado negociando durante semanas, sin éxito. El comisario de Comercio de la UE, Maros Sefcovic, ha viajado siete veces al otro lado del Atlántico. Ha hablado con el secretario de Comercio de EE. UU., Howard Lutnick, el representante comercial de EE. UU., Jamieson Greer, y el asesor económico de Trump, Kevin Hassett, casi todos los días.

El 23 de julio, parecía posible un acuerdo, aunque estaba lejos de estar finalizado, y el impredecible presidente Trump, que tendría la última palabra en Washington, aún no había tomado una decisión. Ese día, el jefe de gabinete de von der Leyen, Bjoern Seibert, presentó un esquema que podría servir de base para un acuerdo a los embajadores de los 27 estados miembros de la UE, para evaluar si los estados miembros estarían dispuestos a seguirlo. Explicó a los diplomáticos que los términos serían los siguientes: todos los bienes europeos, incluidos los productos farmacéuticos, los semiconductores, los automóviles y el acero, estarían sujetos a aranceles del 15% (frente al promedio actual del 4,5%), lo que, más o menos, representaría la confirmación del status quo. Se harían excepciones para el sector aeroespacial y las bebidas espirituosas.

title: China’s Xi urges Europe to make ‘the right strategic choice’ amid global trade turbulence at key summit
content: Chinese leader Xi Jinping urged the European Union to make “the right strategic choice” and enhance cooperation ...
resumen: Chinese leader Xi Jinping urged the European Union to make “the right strategic choice” and enhance cooperation with China. European Council President Antonio Costa and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen met with Xi on Thursday morning and Chinese Premier Li Qiang in the afternoon. The European leaders voiced concerns over a host of issues, from the trade imbalance to China’s support for Russia in the Ukraine war, and Beijing’s chokehold on the rare earths supply chain. Von der Leyen said the EU’s economic ties with China, with a trade deficit of 300 billion euros ($350 billion) last year, had reached “an inflection point.” Costa urged Xi to use China’s influence to end Russia’s war against Ukraine. The summit, whittled from two days to a single day, is meant to celebrate 50 years of diplomatic ties between Beijing and the EU. Xi told Costa and von der Leyen that the challenges faced by Europe “do not come from China” and urged the EU to “properly handle differences and frictions.” Xi called on the bloc to keep its markets open to imports and investment while exercising “restraint” in using restrictive trade and other economic measures. Xi said China and the EU are “constructive forces that support multilateralism and advocate for openness and cooperation.” The EU raised concerns about Beijing’s “ongoing systemic distortions and growing manufacturing overcapacity.” The European leaders urged China to take concrete action to address European businesses’ access to the Chinese market, end “unjustified and retaliatory” trade measures on EU exports, and lift export controls on rare earths and permanent magnets. The EU officials vowed to take “proportionate, legally compliant action” to protect the bloc’s interests if solutions cannot be reached. The EU repeated calls on Beijing not to provide any material support for Russia’s military-industrial base and expressed concerns over China’s policies in Xinjiang, Tibet, and Hong Kong, as well as tensions in the Taiwan Strait and the East and South China Seas. The two sides issued a joint statement on climate, pledging to “demonstrate leadership together” and to draw up plans to reduce planet-heating pollution before the COP30 climate conference in November. The EU has reiterated concerns over inexpensive Chinese goods “flooding” European markets, Beijing’s move to squeeze the rare earths supply chain, and its backing for Russia. Beijing has lashed out against those concerns, including the 27-member bloc’s move last year to raise tariffs on its electric vehicles, launching its own trade probes. The EU announced it was barring Chinese companies from participating in public tenders for medical devices over a certain value, and Beijing hit back with its own curbs on government purchases of Europe-made devices. China’s Ministry of Commerce slammed the EU decision to include two Chinese banks and a handful of other firms in its latest sanctions against Russia. Commerce Minister Wang Wentao lodged representations over the sanctions in a video call with EU trade chief Maros Sefcovic. Von der Leyen made clear the bloc’s deep concerns about Beijing were unresolved. Beijing has extensive control over supply chains for critical minerals key in everything from EV batteries and cell phones to fighter jets.

title: Salió el cobre: aranceles del 50%
content: Desde relatos conmovedores hasta reflexiones provocativas, estas crónicas nos invitan a explorar la complejidad y la diversidad de la vida urbana a través de los ojos y las voces de aquellos que la vi ...
resumen:
El 9 de julio, Donald Trump anunció en Truth Social un nuevo arancel del 50% al cobre, sin importar el país de origen, con fecha de inicio el 1 de agosto de 2025.

El intercambio comercial total de cobre refinado y aleaciones de cobre en 2024 fue de 2,079 millones de dólares, de los cuales 266 millones de dólares corresponden a ventas internacionales y 1,814 millones de dólares a compras internacionales.

En 2023, Puebla encabezó las ventas internacionales por entidad federativa con el 37% de las ventas totales, seguido de Sonora con 34.5%, Nuevo León con 17.7% y Coahuila con 6.49%.

En 2023, los países que más compraron cobre a México fueron China con 40.6%, Estados Unidos con 30.9% y Panamá con 16.6%.

En 2023, CDMX tuvo el mayor porcentaje de compra de cobre con el 79.4%, seguido de Baja California con 8.83%, Nuevo León con 6.23% y el Estado de México con 4.1%.

En 2023, los países que más vendieron cobre a México fueron Estados Unidos con 45% y Perú con 28.1%.

Trump mencionó que el cobre es necesario para semiconductores, aeronaves, barcos, munición, centros de datos, baterías de litio, sistemas de radares, sistemas de defensa de misiles e inclusive armas hipersónicas.

La Presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum mencionó la intención de buscar nuevos socios comerciales y negociar con Estados Unidos.

title: Gobierno y mineras en Chile analizan el arancel del 50% al cobre de Donald Trump
content: Codelco, Sonami, Consejo Minero, BHP, Freeport McMoran, Aprimin, Asociación de Industriales de Antofagasta y la International Copper Association asistieron en representación del sector privado.
resumen:
El gobierno del Presidente Gabriel Boric y representantes de las mineras en Chile analizaron este miércoles el arancel del 50% al cobre que ingrese a Estados Unidos a partir del 1 de agosto.

Del sector minero asistieron el presidente del directorio de Codelco, Máximo Pacheco; el presidente de la Sociedad Nacional de Minería (Sonami), Jorge Riesco; el presidente ejecutivo del Consejo Minero, Joaquín Villarino; el vicepresidente de Asuntos Corporativos Latinoamérica de BHP, René Muga; el country manager de Freeport McMoran, Mario Larenas; la presidenta de la Asociación de Proveedores Industriales de la Minería (Aprimin), Dominique Viera; el gerente general de la Asociación de Industriales de Antofagasta (AIA), Fernando Cortez; y el presidente de la International Copper Association (ICA), Juan Ignacio Díaz (online).

Según informó la subsecretaría de Relaciones Económicas Internacionales (Subrei) en un comunicado, el evento consistió en conocer la visión de las empresas sobre el tema y el Ejecutivo informó las acciones que está realizando “a la espera de conocer más detalles sobre los anuncios aranceles a las importaciones de cobre al mercado estadounidense”.

Actualmente, Estados Unidos es el segundo socio comercial de Chile. Respecto a las exportaciones chilenas de cobre, EE.UU. representó el 11,1% de los envíos de este producto en 2024, con un total de US $5.633,8 millones, siendo casi en su totalidad cátodos y secciones de cátodos refinados, resaltó Subrei.

Tras el encuentro y vía el mismo comunicado del gobierno, el presidente de Sonami, Jorge Riesco, señaló que “estamos muy agradecidos de que consideren la opinión del sector privado. Es importante compartir información, opiniones e impresiones, porque eso va generando un modelamiento mejor del escenario y puede facilitar mejores decisiones”.

En tanto, Juan Ignacio Díaz, presidente de la International Copper Association, comentó que “desde el inicio de la investigación 232 en EE.UU., en la ICA hemos actuado con decisión para proteger la cadena de suministro, defender a los fabricantes estadounidenses y a nuestros productores. Hemos presentado propuestas concretas y fortalecido el trabajo con el Congreso americano. Confiamos en que, gracias a la apertura de Chile al mundo, y sin alejarnos de un aliado clave como EE.UU., saldremos adelante”.

Finalmente, la presidenta de Aprimin, Dominique Viera, señaló que “estamos muy contentos por la invitación a conversar en este grupo sobre las implicancias que pueda tener un arancel sobre el cobre. Nosotros, desde el punto de vista de los proveedores, creemos que puede haber algunos riesgos. Sin embargo, en el largo plazo, al parecer todos coincidimos con que la demanda de minerales críticos va a ser superior”.

Por parte del gobierno participó la ministra de Minería, Aurora Williams; el ministro de Economía, Nicolás Grau; y la subsecretaria de Relaciones Económicas Internacionales (Subrei), Claudia Sanhueza, la vicepresidenta ejecutiva (s) de Cochilco, Claudia Rodríguez; y el embajador de Chile en EE.UU., Juan Gabriel Valdés.

title: Casa Rorty XLVIII: Guerra comercial y globalización en clave cosmopolita
content: Para competir en un mundo globalizado, Occidente debería olvidarse del populismo y el resentimiento y hacer reformas inteligentes.
resumen:
La negación de la ciencia por parte de la Unión Soviética, especialmente en áreas como la genética y la cibernética, tuvo consecuencias devastadoras.

En genética, la promoción de las teorías de Trofim Lysenko, que negaban la genética mendeliana, llevó a la destrucción de la investigación genética y a la implementación de prácticas agrícolas ineficaces, contribuyendo a la hambruna y al fracaso de la producción agrícola.

En cibernética, la URSS inicialmente rechazó la disciplina, considerándola una "ciencia burguesa". Esto retrasó el desarrollo de la informática y la tecnología de la información, lo que afectó negativamente la capacidad de la URSS para competir tecnológicamente con Occidente.

La supresión de la investigación científica y la imposición de ideologías políticas sobre la ciencia obstaculizaron el progreso científico y tecnológico en la URSS, con graves consecuencias económicas y sociales.

title: War between India, Pak would have ended nuclear: Trump
content: US President Donald Trump on Tuesday claimed yet again that he stopped the recent "war" between India and Pakistan and that five planes were shot down in the conflict.
resumen: On July 24, 2025, US President Donald Trump claimed he stopped the recent “war” between India and Pakistan and that five planes were shot down in the conflict. He also claimed the conflict between India and Pakistan “was probably going to end up in a nuclear war”. Trump said he stopped wars between India and Pakistan, the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Rwanda. He added that he called them and said, ‘Listen, no more trade. If you do this, you’re not going to be good…They’re both powerful nuclear nations and that would have happened, and who knows where that would have ended up. And I stopped it’. Trump claimed the US took out Iran’s entire nuclear capability and also stopped the conflict between Kosovo and Serbia. Trump said that five jets were shot down during the fighting. Acting US Representative Ambassador Dorothy Shea said at an open debate in the UN Security Council on Tuesday on ‘Multilateralism and Peaceful Settlement of Disputes’ that the United States continues to work with parties to disputes, wherever possible, to find peaceful solutions. Shea said that in the past three months alone, “we have seen the US leadership deliver de-escalations between Israel and Iran, between the Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda, and between India and Pakistan.”.

title: Logistics rents extend slump in China as suppliers relocate to hedge against tariff war
content: Logistics property owners are losing out to their rivals in India, where rents increased this year from the second half of 2024.
resumen: Rents on logistics properties in mainland China extended a slump into the first half of this year. Rents declined 12.8 per cent in the first six months from a year earlier, according to Knight Frank. The market weakened by 14.1 per cent in the July to December period last year. Beijing and Shanghai highlighted the shrinking demand as rents tumbled 17.2 per cent and 11.3 per cent, respectively, this year. The vacancy rate climbed to 28.9 per cent in Beijing and 26.8 per cent in Shanghai. The prospect of rents bottoming out is unlikely within the next 12 months, according to Christine Li, Asia-Pacific head of research at Knight Frank. India reported the strongest logistics rental growth in the Asia-Pacific region. Rents climbed 3.4 per cent, versus 2.1 per cent in the second half of 2024.

title: US automakers say Trump's 15% tariff deal with Japan puts them at a disadvantage
content: U.S. automakers worry that President Donald Trump’s agreement to tariff Japanese vehicles at 15% would put them at a competitive disadvantage, saying they will face steeper import taxes on steel, ...
resumen:
U.S. automakers worry that President Donald Trump’s agreement to tariff Japanese vehicles at 15% would put them at a competitive disadvantage, saying they will face steeper import taxes on steel, aluminum and parts than their competitors.

Matt Blunt, president of the American Automotive Policy Council, which represents the Big 3 American automakers, General Motors, Ford and Jeep-maker Stellantis, said the U.S. companies and workers “definitely are at a disadvantage” because they face a 50% tariff on steel and aluminum and a 25% tariff on parts and finished vehicles, with some exceptions for products covered under the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement that went into effect in 2020.

The United Auto Workers said in a statement it was “deeply angered” by the deal.

Trump portrayed the trade framework as a major win after announcing it on Tuesday, saying it would add hundreds of thousands of jobs to the U.S. economy and open the Japanese economy in ways that could close a persistent trade imbalance.

The agreement includes a 15% tariff that replaces the 25% import tax the Republican president had threatened to charge starting on Aug. 1.

Japan would also put together $550 billion to invest in U.S. projects at the “direction” of the president, the White House said.

The framework with Japan will remove regulations that prevent American vehicles from being sold in that country, the White House has said.

Karl Brauer, executive analyst at iSeeCars, said the agreement provides Japan with a near-term operating cost advantage compared to other foreign automakers, and even some domestic U.S. product that uses a high degree of both foreign production and parts content.

Autos Drive America, an organization that represents major Japanese companies Toyota, Honda and Nissan and other international automakers, said in a statement that it is “encouraged” by the announced trade framework and noted its members have exceeded domestic automaker production for the past two years.

The statement urged "the Trump administration to swiftly reach similar agreements with other allies and partners, especially the European Union, South Korea, Canada and Mexico.”

Sam Fiorani, vice president at consultancy AutoForecast Solutions, said Ford, GM and Stellantis do “have every right to be upset.”

title: Trump reafirma que a los países con los que no alcance un acuerdo les impondrá en agosto aranceles del 15 al 50 %
content: Donald Trump reafirmó que a los países con los que no alcance un acuerdo antes del 1 de agosto les impondrá aranceles. de hasta el 50% ...
resumen:
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, reafirmó este miércoles que a los países con los que no alcance un acuerdo individual antes del 1 de agosto les impondrá aranceles que oscilarán del 15 al 50 %.

Trump impuso en abril -y luego pausó- un régimen arancelario global del 10 % junto con gravámenes considerados «recíprocos» para reducir el déficit comercial con sus socios, a quienes dio como plazo inicial el 9 de julio para negociar pactos, margen que luego extendió de forma definitiva al 1 de agosto.

Durante esta tregua, EE.UU. solo ha cerrado acuerdos con el Reino Unido, Japón, Vietnam, Indonesia, Filipinas y China. Este último fue un convenio temporal que redujo los aranceles estadounidenses del 145 % al 30 % y los gravámenes chinos del 125 % al 10 % mientras continúan las negociaciones.

A falta de acuerdos, el mandatario ha enviado ya cartas notificando aranceles de entre el 20 % y el 40 % a decenas de países, incluidos sus vecinos México (30 %) y Canadá (35 %). A Brasil lo amenazó con un 50 % por el enjuiciamiento a su aliado, el expresidente Jair Bolsonaro.

Trump ha amenazado a la Unión Europea con gravámenes del 30 %, pero fuentes diplomáticas confirmaron este miércoles a EFE que ambas partes se encuentran más cerca de cerrar un acuerdo de aranceles del 15 % a los productos europeos.

title: Empresas empiezan a resentir impactos financieros de aranceles de Trump
content: Empresas que fabrican de todo, desde chips hasta acero, reportaron resultados con tendencias a la baja este miércoles, con la guerra comercial del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, ...
resumen:
Empresas que fabrican de todo, desde chips hasta acero, reportaron resultados con tendencias a la baja este miércoles, con la guerra comercial del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, infligiendo daños incluso pese a que su pacto con Japón impulsó las acciones y las esperanzas de que Europa haga lo mismo.

Las bolsas asiáticas y europeas subieron, ya que los inversionistas aplaudieron el acuerdo comercial entre Estados Unidos y Japón, que rebaja los aranceles a las importaciones de autos y evita a Tokio nuevos gravámenes sobre otros bienes.

Los resultados de Texas Instruments y del fabricante de acero SSAB mostraron cómo la caótica política comercial estadounidense ya ha perjudicado a los beneficios, aumentando los costos, trastornando las cadenas de suministro y lastrando la confianza de los consumidores.

El informe trimestral de resultados de Texas Instruments apuntó a una demanda de sus chips analógicos menor de lo esperado por parte de algunos clientes y subrayó la incertidumbre arancelaria.

Fabricantes de semiconductores como Texas Instruments aún no se enfrentan directamente a los elevados aranceles de Trump, pero el costo de las herramientas de fabricación ha aumentado y algunos de sus clientes finales han recortado el gasto.

El fabricante holandés de equipos para chips informáticos ASM International advirtió de que la entrada de pedidos de los fabricantes fue “irregular” en el segundo trimestre.

Neil Wilson, estratega de inversiones de Saxo Markets, afirmó que “los aranceles están golpeando fuerte”.

Las empresas informaron de una pérdida combinada para todo el año de entre 6 mil 600 y 7 mil 800 millones de dólares entre el 16 y el 22 de julio, siendo los sectores automovilístico, aeroespacial y farmacéutico los más perjudicados.

General Motors reiteró el martes su expectativa de un golpe de entre 4 mil y 5 mil millones de dólares por los aranceles para 2025.

La finlandesa Nokia acusó a los vientos en contra de los aranceles y a la debilidad del dólar al rebajar sus previsiones para 2025.

Para la siderúrgica sueca SSAB, el mayor problema es que los aranceles están provocando que más envíos de acero barato se redirijan a Europa.

Johnny Sjostrom, presidente ejecutivo de SSAB, dijo que “Las turbulencias de los aranceles y las barreras comerciales provocaron un aumento de la incertidumbre”, con el mayor impacto visto en el debilitamiento del mercado europeo del acero.

Aunque el acuerdo con Japón alivió las preocupaciones de los inversores, persiste la amenaza de aranceles más altos en otras grandes economías, como la Unión Europea, Canadá y Brasil.

Trump también ha amenazado con gravámenes sectoriales más elevados sobre los productos farmacéuticos, los chips y el cobre.

Los analistas de Deutsche Bank dijeron que esto está lejos del final.

title: Brasil lamenta la falta de diálogo con Estados Unidos para buscar solución a aranceles impuestos por Trump
content: Río de Janeiro, 24 jul (Xinhua) -- El Gobierno brasileño lamentó hoy la falta de diálogo con la Casa Blanca para buscar una solución negociada a la imposición de aranceles del 50 por ciento anunciada ...
resumen: El Gobierno brasileño lamentó la falta de diálogo con la Casa Blanca para buscar una solución negociada a la imposición de aranceles del 50 por ciento anunciada por el presidente estadounidense Donald Trump a todas las importaciones brasileñas a partir del 1 de agosto. El ministro de Hacienda, Fernando Haddad, reiteró que el Gobierno brasileño sigue apostando por una salida negociada con Estados Unidos, pero lamentó la falta de diálogo con la Casa Blanca. Haddad explicó que están conversando con el equipo técnico del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, pero no con el secretario Scott Bessent. El vicepresidente Geraldo Alckmin logró mantener contactos con algunos funcionarios estadounidenses, aunque sin obtener respuesta directa del Gobierno de Trump. Haddad afirmó que Brasil tiene un punto válido y que tiene razón en pedir sentarse a la mesa, pero el tema está muy concentrado en el equipo de asesores de la Casa Blanca. Haddad expresó cierto optimismo y recordó que Brasil logró cerrar recientemente acuerdos bilaterales con Vietnam, Japón, Indonesia y Filipinas. Mencionó avances en las negociaciones entre Estados Unidos y la Unión Europea como un posible estímulo para que Washington flexibilice su postura frente a Brasil. Haddad avanzó que Brasil finalizó el diseño de un plan de contingencia para asistir a los sectores económicos más afectados por la imposición de aranceles del 50 por ciento por parte del gobierno estadounidense y que las medidas serán presentadas la próxima semana al presidente Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. El plan fue elaborado siguiendo parámetros definidos por el propio Haddad y por el vicepresidente y ministro de Desarrollo, Industria, Comercio y Servicios, Geraldo Alckmin. Ahora deberá ser revisado por los ministros de Relaciones Exteriores, Mauro Vieira, y de la Casa Civil, Rui Costa, antes de ser sometido a la decisión final del presidente Lula.

title: Brasil enfrenta a Trump en la OMC por el uso político de los aranceles
content: El gobierno de Lula denunció ante la OMC que la Casa Blanca impone tasas “arbitrarias y caóticas” para presionar a otros países. Alertó sobre los riesgos de una escalada global que afecte sobre todo a ...
resumen: El gobierno de Brasil presentó una denuncia formal ante la Organización Mundial del Comercio (OMC) contra la imposición de tasas "arbitrarias y aplicadas de forma caótica" por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump. El secretario de Asuntos Económicos del Ministerio de Asuntos Exteriores brasileño, Philip Gough, advirtió que políticas como la impulsada por la administración de Trump pueden empujar la economía global hacia una “espiral de precios altos y estancamiento”. Criticó el uso de tasas como instrumento para influir en los asuntos internos de otros países, señalándola como una estrategia “extremadamente peligrosa” que atenta contra el equilibrio del sistema multilateral. Brasil mantiene su compromiso con el diálogo para la resolución de disputas comerciales, pero que, si esa instancia resulta inviable, el país está preparado para utilizar todos los mecanismos legales disponibles, incluida la mediación de la OMC. Brasil denunció un preocupante giro en el uso de aranceles como herramienta de presión política. Según Gough, más allá de las violaciones sistemáticas a las reglas del comercio internacional, “lo más preocupante es el intento de emplear medidas arancelarias para interferir en los asuntos internos de países soberanos”. Brasil ha insistido en que es esencial que la OMC recupere su papel como un lugar "donde todos los países pueden resolver disputas y hacer valer intereses legítimos a través del diálogo y la negociación". 40 países (27 de ellos pertenecientes a la Unión Europea) manifestaron su apoyo a la defensa del multilateralismo y la urgencia de reformar organismos como la OMC. Entre ellos figuran China, India, Canadá y Colombia. El presidente estadounidense indicó que estaría dispuesto a revisar las medidas arancelarias si sus socios comerciales eliminan las “barreras” que afectan sus exportaciones. De lo contrario, advirtió que los gravámenes podrían aumentar. Las sanciones anunciadas por Trump contra Brasil están basadas en argumentos que van desde “la forma en que Brasil trató al expresidente Bolsonaro...” y “los ataques insidiosos de Brasil a las elecciones libres y los derechos fundamentales de libertad de expresión...” hasta la “muy injusta relación comercial de larga data” que sostienen con Estados Unidos. Brasil reporta una relación comercial superavitaria de 450 mil millones de dólares con Estados Unidos, y es uno de los países con mayor presencia de filiales de empresas de esa nación. Brasil ocupa el puesto 13 en el ranking global, con 4.686 compañías extranjeras operando en su territorio.
